scenes.location: A hall in the Duke's palace

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: Proceed, Solinus, to procure my fall, And by the doom of death end woes and all.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Merchant of Syracusa, plead no more. I am not partial to infringe our laws. The enmity and discord which of late Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your Duke To merchants, our well-dealing countrymen, Who, wanting guilders to redeem their lives, Have seal'd his rigorous statutes with their bloods, Excludes all pity from our threat'ning looks. For since the mortal and intestine jars 'Twixt thy seditious countrymen and us, It hath in solemn synods been decreed, Both by the Syracusians and ourselves, To admit no traffic to our adverse towns; Nay more, if any born at Ephesus Be seen at Syracusian marts and fairs; Again, if any Syracusian born Come to the bay of Ephesus, he dies, His goods confiscate to the Duke's dispose, Unless a thousand marks be levied To quit the penalty and to ransom him. Thy substance, valued at the highest rate, Cannot amount unto a hundred marks; Therefore by law thou art condemn'd to die.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: Yet this my comfort; when your words are done, My woes end likewise with the evening sun.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Well, Syracusian, say in brief the cause Why thou departedst from thy native home, And for what cause thou cam'st to Ephesus.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: A heavier task could not have been impos'd Than I to speak my griefs unspeakable; Yet, that the world may witness that my end Was wrought by nature, not by vile offence, I'll utter what my sorrow gives me leave. In Syracusa was I born, and wed Unto a woman happy but for me, And by me, had not our hap been bad. With her I liv'd in joy; our wealth increas'd By prosperous voyages I often made To Epidamnum, till my factor's death, And the great care of goods at random left, Drew me from kind embracements of my spouse; From whom my absence was not six months old Before herself (almost at fainting under The pleasing punishment that women bear) Had made provision for her following me, And soon and safe arrived where I was. There had she not been long but she became A joyful mother of two goodly sons, And, which was strange, the one so like the other As could not be distinguish'd but by names. That very hour, and in the self-same inn, A mean woman was delivered Of such a burden, male twins, both alike. Those, for their parents were exceeding poor, I bought, and brought up to attend my sons. My wife, not meanly proud of two such boys, Made daily motions for our home return. Unwilling I agreed; alas, too soon We came aboard. A league from Epidamnum had we sail'd Before the always-wind-obeying deep Gave any tragic instance of our harm; But longer did we not retain much hope; For what obscured light the heavens did grant Did but convey unto our fearful minds A doubtful warrant of immediate death, Which though myself would gladly have embrac'd, Yet the incessant weepings of my wife, Weeping before for what she saw must come, And piteous plainings of the pretty babes, That mourn'd for fashion, ignorant what to fear, Forc'd me to seek delays for them and me. And this it was (for other means was none). The sailors sought for safety by our boat, And left the ship, then sinking-ripe, to us. My wife, more careful for the latter-born, Had fast'ned him unto a small spare mast, Such as sea-faring men provide for storms. To him one of the other twins was bound, Whilst I had been like heedful of the other. The children thus dispos'd, my wife and I, Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fix'd, Fast'ned ourselves at either end the mast, And, floating straight, obedient to the stream, Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought. At length the sun, gazing upon the earth, Dispers'd those vapours that offended us, And by the benefit of his wished light The seas wax'd calm, and we discovered Two ships from far, making amain to us, Of Corinth that, of Epidaurus this. But ere they came-O, let me say no more! Gather the sequel by that went before.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Nay, forward, old man, do not break off so, For we may pity, though not pardon thee.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: O, had the gods done so, I had not now Worthily term'd them merciless to us. For, ere the ships could meet by twice five leagues, We were encountered by a mighty rock, Which being violently borne upon, Our helpful ship was splitted in the midst; So that, in this unjust divorce of us, Fortune had left to both of us alike What to delight in, what to sorrow for. Her part, poor soul, seeming as burdened With lesser weight, but not with lesser woe, Was carried with more speed before the wind, And in our sight they three were taken up By fishermen of Corinth, as we thought. At length another ship had seiz'd on us; And, knowing whom it was their hap to save, Gave healthful welcome to their ship-wrack'd guests, And would have reft the fishers of their prey, Had not their bark been very slow of sail; And therefore homeward did they bend their course. Thus have you heard me sever'd from my bliss, That by misfortunes was my life prolong'd To tell sad stories of my own mishaps.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: And for the sake of them thou sorrowest for, Do me the favour to dilate at full What have befall'n of them and thee till now.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: My youngest boy, and yet my eldest care, At eighteen years became inquisitive After his brother, and importun'd me That his attendant, so his case was like, Reft of his brother, but retain'd his name, Might bear him company in the quest of him; Whom whilst I laboured of a love to see, I hazarded the loss of whom I lov'd. Five summers have I spent in farthest Greece, Roaming clean through the bounds of Asia, And, coasting homeward, came to Ephesus, Hopeless to find, yet loath to leave unsought Or that or any place that harbours men. But here must end the story of my life; And happy were I in my timely death, Could all my travels warrant me they live.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Hapless Egeon, whom the fates have mark'd To bear the extremity of dire mishap; Now, trust me, were it not against our laws, Against my crown, my oath, my dignity, Which princes, would they, may not disannul, My soul should sue as advocate for thee. But though thou art adjudged to the death, And passed sentence may not be recall'd But to our honour's great disparagement, Yet will I favour thee in what I can. Therefore, merchant, I'll limit thee this day To seek thy health by beneficial help. Try all the friends thou hast in Ephesus; Beg thou, or borrow, to make up the sum, And live; if no, then thou art doom'd to die. Jailer, take him to thy custody.

dialogues.speaker: Jailer
dialogues.line: I will, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: Hopeless and helpless doth Egeon wend, But to procrastinate his lifeless end.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum, Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate. This very day a Syracusian merchant Is apprehended for arrival here, And, not being able to buy out his life, According to the statute of the town There is your money that I had to keep.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Go bear it to the Centaur, where we host, And stay there, Dromio, till I come to thee. Within this hour it will be dinnertime; Till that, I'll view the manners of the town, Peruse the traders, gaze upon the buildings, And then return and sleep within mine inn, For with long travel I am stiff and weary. Get thee away.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Many a man would take you at your word, And go indeed, having so good a mean.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: A trusty villain, sir, that very oft, When I am dull with care and melancholy, Lightens my humour with his merry jests. What, will you walk with me about the town, And then go to my inn and dine with me?

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: I am invited, sir, to certain merchants, Of whom I hope to make much benefit. I crave your pardon. Soon, at five o'clock, Please you, I'll meet with you upon the mart, And afterward consort you till bedtime. My present business calls me from you now.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Farewell till then: I will go lose myself, And wander up and down to view the city.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: Sir, I commend you to your own content.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: He that commends me to mine own content Commends me to the thing I cannot get. I to the world am like a drop of water That in the ocean seeks another drop, Who, failing there to find his fellow forth, Unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself. So I, to find a mother and a brother, In quest of them, unhappy, lose myself. Here comes the almanac of my true date. What now? How chance thou art return'd so soon?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Return'd so soon? rather approach'd too late. The capon burns, the pig falls from the spit; The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bell; My mistress made it one upon my cheek. She is so hot because the meat is cold; The meat is cold because you come not home; You come not home because you have no stomach; You have no stomach, having broke your fast; But we that know what 'tis to fast and pray, Are penitent for your default today.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Stop in your wind, sir, tell me this, I pray: Where have you left the money that I gave you?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: O, sixpence that I had o' Wednesday last To pay the saddler for my mistress' crupper: The saddler had it, sir, I kept it not.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I am not in a sportive humour now. Tell me, and dally not, where is the money? We being strangers here, how dar'st thou trust So great a charge from thine own custody?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I pray you jest, sir, as you sit at dinner: I from my mistress come to you in post; If I return, I shall be post indeed, For she will score your fault upon my pate. Methinks your maw, like mine, should be your clock, And strike you home without a messenger.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Come, Dromio, come, these jests are out of season, Reserve them till a merrier hour than this. Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: To me, sir? why, you gave no gold to me!

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Come on, sir knave, have done your foolishness, And tell me how thou hast dispos'd thy charge.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: My charge was but to fetch you from the mart Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner. My mistress and her sister stay for you.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Now, as I am a Christian, answer me In what safe place you have bestow'd my money, Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours That stands on tricks when I am undispos'd; Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I have some marks of yours upon my pate, Some of my mistress' marks upon my shoulders, But not a thousand marks between you both. If I should pay your worship those again, Perchance you will not bear them patiently.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Thy mistress' marks? what mistress, slave, hast thou?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Your worship's wife, my mistress at the Phoenix; She that doth fast till you come home to dinner, And prays that you will hie you home to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: What, wilt thou flout me thus unto my face, Being forbid? There, take you that, sir knave.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: What mean you, sir? for God's sake hold your hands. Nay, an you will not, sir, I'll take my heels.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Upon my life, by some device or other The villain is o'er-raught of all my money. They say this town is full of cozenage, As nimble jugglers that deceive the eye, Dark-working sorcerers that change the mind, Soul-killing witches that deform the body, Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks, And many such-like liberties of sin: If it prove so, I will be gone the sooner. I'll to the Centaur to go seek this slave. I greatly fear my money is not safe.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Neither my husband nor the slave return'd That in such haste I sent to seek his master? Sure, Luciana, it is two o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Perhaps some merchant hath invited him, And from the mart he's somewhere gone to dinner. Good sister, let us dine, and never fret; A man is master of his liberty; Time is their master, and when they see time, They'll go or come. If so, be patient, sister.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Why should their liberty than ours be more?

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Because their business still lies out o' door.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Look when I serve him so, he takes it ill.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: O, know he is the bridle of your will.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: There's none but asses will be bridled so.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Why, headstrong liberty is lash'd with woe. There's nothing situate under heaven's eye But hath his bound in earth, in sea, in sky. The beasts, the fishes, and the winged fowls Are their males' subjects, and at their controls. Man, more divine, the masters of all these, Lord of the wide world and wild wat'ry seas, Indued with intellectual sense and souls, Of more pre-eminence than fish and fowls, Are masters to their females, and their lords: Then let your will attend on their accords.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: This servitude makes you to keep unwed.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Not this, but troubles of the marriage-bed.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: But, were you wedded, you would bear some sway.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Ere I learn love, I'll practise to obey.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: How if your husband start some other where?

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Till he come home again, I would forbear.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Patience unmov'd! No marvel though she pause; They can be meek that have no other cause. A wretched soul bruis'd with adversity, We bid be quiet when we hear it cry; But were we burd'ned with like weight of pain, As much, or more, we should ourselves complain: So thou, that hast no unkind mate to grieve thee, With urging helpless patience would relieve me: But if thou live to see like right bereft, This fool-begg'd patience in thee will be left.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Well, I will marry one day, but to try. Here comes your man, now is your husband nigh.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Say, is your tardy master now at hand?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Nay, he's at two hands with me, and that my two ears can witness.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Say, didst thou speak with him? know'st thou his mind?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Ay, ay, he told his mind upon mine ear. Beshrew his hand, I scarce could understand it.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Spake he so doubtfully thou couldst not feel his meaning?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Nay, he struck so plainly I could too well feel his blows; and withal so doubtfully that I could scarce understand them.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: But say, I prithee, is he coming home? It seems he hath great care to please his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Why, mistress, sure my master is horn-mad.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Horn-mad, thou villain?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I mean not cuckold-mad, But sure he's stark mad. When I desir'd him to come home to dinner, He ask'd me for a thousand marks in gold. "'Tis dinner time," quoth I. "My gold," quoth he. "Your meat doth burn" quoth I. "My gold," quoth he. "Will you come home?" quoth I. "My gold," quoth he. "Where is the thousand marks I gave thee, villain?" "The pig" quoth I "is burn'd". "My gold," quoth he. "My mistress, sir," quoth I. "Hang up thy mistress; I know not thy mistress; out on thy mistress!"

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Quoth who?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Quoth my master. "I know," quoth he, "no house, no wife, no mistress." So that my errand, due unto my tongue, I thank him, I bare home upon my shoulders; For, in conclusion, he did beat me there.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Go back again, thou slave, and fetch him home.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Go back again, and be new beaten home? For God's sake, send some other messenger.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Back slave, or I will break thy pate across.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: And he will bless that cross with other beating. Between you I shall have a holy head.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Hence, prating peasant. Fetch thy master home.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Am I so round with you, as you with me, That like a football you do spurn me thus? You spurn me hence, and he will spurn me hither. If I last in this service, you must case me in leather.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Fie, how impatience loureth in your face.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: His company must do his minions grace, Whilst I at home starve for a merry look. Hath homely age th' alluring beauty took From my poor cheek? then he hath wasted it. Are my discourses dull? barren my wit? If voluble and sharp discourse be marr'd, Unkindness blunts it more than marble hard. Do their gay vestments his affections bait? That's not my fault; he's master of my state. What ruins are in me that can be found By him not ruin'd? Then is he the ground Of my defeatures. My decayed fair A sunny look of his would soon repair; But, too unruly deer, he breaks the pale And feeds from home; poor I am but his stale.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Self-harming jealousy! fie, beat it hence.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Unfeeling fools can with such wrongs dispense. I know his eye doth homage otherwhere, Or else what lets it but he would be here? Sister, you know he promis'd me a chain; Would that alone, a love he would detain, So he would keep fair quarter with his bed. I see the jewel best enamelled Will lose his beauty; yet the gold bides still That others touch, yet often touching will Wear gold; and no man that hath a name By falsehood and corruption doth it shame. Since that my beauty cannot please his eye, I'll weep what's left away, and weeping die.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: How many fond fools serve mad jealousy!

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: The gold I gave to Dromio is laid up Safe at the Centaur, and the heedful slave Is wander'd forth in care to seek me out. By computation and mine host's report. I could not speak with Dromio since at first I sent him from the mart. See, here he comes. How now, sir! is your merry humour alter'd? As you love strokes, so jest with me again. You know no Centaur? you receiv'd no gold? Your mistress sent to have me home to dinner? My house was at the Phoenix? Wast thou mad, That thus so madly thou didst answer me?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: What answer, sir? when spake I such a word?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Even now, even here, not half an hour since.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I did not see you since you sent me hence, Home to the Centaur with the gold you gave me.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Villain, thou didst deny the gold's receipt, And told'st me of a mistress and a dinner, For which I hope thou felt'st I was displeas'd.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I am glad to see you in this merry vein. What means this jest, I pray you, master, tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Yea, dost thou jeer and flout me in the teeth? Think'st thou I jest? Hold, take thou that, and that.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Hold, sir, for God's sake, now your jest is earnest. Upon what bargain do you give it me?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Because that I familiarly sometimes Do use you for my fool, and chat with you, Your sauciness will jest upon my love, And make a common of my serious hours. When the sun shines let foolish gnats make sport, But creep in crannies when he hides his beams. If you will jest with me, know my aspect, And fashion your demeanour to my looks, Or I will beat this method in your sconce.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Sconce, call you it? so you would leave battering, I had rather have it a head. And you use these blows long, I must get a sconce for my head, and ensconce it too, or else I shall seek my wit in my shoulders. But I pray, sir, why am I beaten?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Dost thou not know?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Nothing, sir, but that I am beaten.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Shall I tell you why?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, and wherefore; for they say, every why hath a wherefore.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Why, first, for flouting me; and then wherefore, For urging it the second time to me.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Was there ever any man thus beaten out of season, When in the why and the wherefore is neither rhyme nor reason? Well, sir, I thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Thank me, sir, for what?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, for this something that you gave me for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I'll make you amends next, to give you nothing for something. But say, sir, is it dinner-time?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: No, sir; I think the meat wants that I have.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: In good time, sir, what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Basting.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Well, sir, then 'twill be dry.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: If it be, sir, I pray you eat none of it.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Your reason?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Lest it make you choleric, and purchase me another dry basting.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Well, sir, learn to jest in good time. There's a time for all things.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I durst have denied that before you were so choleric.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: By what rule, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, by a rule as plain as the plain bald pate of Father Time himself.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Let's hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: There's no time for a man to recover his hair that grows bald by nature.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: May he not do it by fine and recovery?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Yes, to pay a fine for a periwig, and recover the lost hair of another man.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Why is Time such a niggard of hair, being, as it is, so plentiful an excrement?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Because it is a blessing that he bestows on beasts, and what he hath scanted men in hair he hath given them in wit.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Why, but there's many a man hath more hair than wit.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Not a man of those but he hath the wit to lose his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Why, thou didst conclude hairy men plain dealers without wit.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: The plainer dealer, the sooner lost. Yet he loseth it in a kind of jollity.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: For what reason?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: For two, and sound ones too.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Nay, not sound, I pray you.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Sure ones, then.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Nay, not sure, in a thing falsing.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Certain ones, then.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Name them.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: The one, to save the money that he spends in tiring; the other, that at dinner they should not drop in his porridge.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: You would all this time have proved there is no time for all things.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Marry, and did, sir; namely, e'en no time to recover hair lost by nature.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: But your reason was not substantial why there is no time to recover.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Thus I mend it: Time himself is bald, and therefore, to the world's end will have bald followers.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I knew 'twould be a bald conclusion. But soft! who wafts us yonder?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Ay, ay, Antipholus, look strange and frown, Some other mistress hath thy sweet aspects. I am not Adriana, nor thy wife. The time was once when thou unurg'd wouldst vow That never words were music to thine ear, That never object pleasing in thine eye, That never touch well welcome to thy hand, That never meat sweet-savour'd in thy taste, Unless I spake, or look'd, or touch'd, or carv'd to thee. How comes it now, my husband, O, how comes it, That thou art then estranged from thyself? Thyself I call it, being strange to me, That, undividable, incorporate, Am better than thy dear self's better part. Ah, do not tear away thyself from me; For know, my love, as easy mayst thou fall A drop of water in the breaking gulf, And take unmingled thence that drop again Without addition or diminishing, As take from me thyself, and not me too. How dearly would it touch thee to the quick, Should'st thou but hear I were licentious? And that this body, consecrate to thee, By ruffian lust should be contaminate? Wouldst thou not spit at me, and spurn at me, And hurl the name of husband in my face, And tear the stain'd skin off my harlot brow, And from my false hand cut the wedding-ring, And break it with a deep-divorcing vow? I know thou canst; and therefore, see thou do it. I am possess'd with an adulterate blot; My blood is mingled with the crime of lust; For if we two be one, and thou play false, I do digest the poison of thy flesh, Being strumpeted by thy contagion. Keep then fair league and truce with thy true bed, I live distain'd, thou undishonoured.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Plead you to me, fair dame? I know you not. In Ephesus I am but two hours old, As strange unto your town as to your talk, Who, every word by all my wit being scann'd, Wants wit in all one word to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Fie, brother, how the world is chang'd with you. When were you wont to use my sister thus? She sent for you by Dromio home to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: By Dromio?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: By me?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: By thee; and this thou didst return from him, That he did buffet thee, and in his blows Denied my house for his, me for his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Did you converse, sir, with this gentlewoman? What is the course and drift of your compact?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I, sir? I never saw her till this time.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Villain, thou liest, for even her very words Didst thou deliver to me on the mart.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I never spake with her in all my life.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: How can she thus, then, call us by our names? Unless it be by inspiration.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: How ill agrees it with your gravity To counterfeit thus grossly with your slave, Abetting him to thwart me in my mood; Be it my wrong, you are from me exempt, But wrong not that wrong with a more contempt. Come, I will fasten on this sleeve of thine. Thou art an elm, my husband, I a vine, Whose weakness, married to thy stronger state, Makes me with thy strength to communicate: If aught possess thee from me, it is dross, Usurping ivy, brier, or idle moss, Who all, for want of pruning, with intrusion Infect thy sap, and live on thy confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: To me she speaks; she moves me for her theme. What, was I married to her in my dream? Or sleep I now, and think I hear all this? What error drives our eyes and ears amiss? Until I know this sure uncertainty I'll entertain the offer'd fallacy.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Dromio, go bid the servants spread for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: O, for my beads! I cross me for a sinner. This is the fairy land; O spite of spites! We talk with goblins, owls, and sprites; If we obey them not, this will ensue: They'll suck our breath, or pinch us black and blue.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Why prat'st thou to thyself, and answer'st not? Dromio, thou drone, thou snail, thou slug, thou sot.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I am transformed, master, am I not?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I think thou art in mind, and so am I.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Nay, master, both in mind and in my shape.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Thou hast thine own form.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: No, I am an ape.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: If thou art chang'd to aught, 'tis to an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: 'Tis true; she rides me, and I long for grass. 'Tis so, I am an ass; else it could never be But I should know her as well as she knows me.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Come, come, no longer will I be a fool, To put the finger in the eye and weep Whilst man and master laughs my woes to scorn. Come, sir, to dinner; Dromio, keep the gate. Husband, I'll dine above with you today, And shrive you of a thousand idle pranks. Sirrah, if any ask you for your master, Say he dines forth, and let no creature enter. Come, sister; Dromio, play the porter well.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Am I in earth, in heaven, or in hell? Sleeping or waking, mad, or well-advis'd? Known unto these, and to myself disguis'd! I'll say as they say, and persever so, And in this mist at all adventures go.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Master, shall I be porter at the gate?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Ay; and let none enter, lest I break your pate.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Come, come, Antipholus, we dine too late.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Good Signior Angelo, you must excuse us all, My wife is shrewish when I keep not hours. Say that I linger'd with you at your shop To see the making of her carcanet, And that tomorrow you will bring it home. But here's a villain that would face me down. He met me on the mart, and that I beat him, And charg'd him with a thousand marks in gold, And that I did deny my wife and house. Thou drunkard, thou, what didst thou mean by this?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Say what you will, sir, but I know what I know. That you beat me at the mart I have your hand to show; If the skin were parchment, and the blows you gave were ink, Your own handwriting would tell you what I think.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I think thou art an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Marry, so it doth appear By the wrongs I suffer and the blows I bear. I should kick, being kick'd; and being at that pass, You would keep from my heels, and beware of an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: You're sad, Signior Balthasar; pray God our cheer May answer my good will and your good welcome here.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: I hold your dainties cheap, sir, and your welcome dear.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: O, Signior Balthasar, either at flesh or fish A table full of welcome makes scarce one dainty dish.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: Good meat, sir, is common; that every churl affords.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: And welcome more common, for that's nothing but words.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: Small cheer and great welcome makes a merry feast.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Ay, to a niggardly host and more sparing guest. But though my cates be mean, take them in good part; Better cheer may you have, but not with better heart. But soft; my door is lock'd. Go bid them let us in.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Maud, Bridget, Marian, Cicely, Gillian, Ginn!

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Mome, malt-horse, capon, coxcomb, idiot, patch! Either get thee from the door or sit down at the hatch: Dost thou conjure for wenches, that thou call'st for such store When one is one too many? Go, get thee from the door.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: What patch is made our porter? My master stays in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Let him walk from whence he came, lest he catch cold on's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Who talks within there? Ho, open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Right, sir, I'll tell you when an you'll tell me wherefore.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Wherefore? For my dinner. I have not dined today.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Nor today here you must not; come again when you may.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: What art thou that keep'st me out from the house I owe?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: The porter for this time, sir, and my name is Dromio.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: O villain, thou hast stolen both mine office and my name; The one ne'er got me credit, the other mickle blame. If thou hadst been Dromio today in my place, Thou wouldst have chang'd thy face for a name, or thy name for an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Luce
dialogues.line: What a coil is there, Dromio, who are those at the gate?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Let my master in, Luce.

dialogues.speaker: Luce
dialogues.line: Faith, no, he comes too late, And so tell your master.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: O Lord, I must laugh; Have at you with a proverb:-Shall I set in my staff?

dialogues.speaker: Luce
dialogues.line: Have at you with another: that's-When? can you tell?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: If thy name be called Luce,-Luce, thou hast answer'd him well.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Do you hear, you minion? you'll let us in, I hope?

dialogues.speaker: Luce
dialogues.line: I thought to have ask'd you.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: And you said no.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: So, come, help. Well struck, there was blow for blow.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Thou baggage, let me in.

dialogues.speaker: Luce
dialogues.line: Can you tell for whose sake?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Master, knock the door hard.

dialogues.speaker: Luce
dialogues.line: Let him knock till it ache.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: You'll cry for this, minion, if I beat the door down.

dialogues.speaker: Luce
dialogues.line: What needs all that, and a pair of stocks in the town?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Who is that at the door that keeps all this noise?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: By my troth, your town is troubled with unruly boys.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Are you there, wife? you might have come before.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Your wife, sir knave? go, get you from the door.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: If you went in pain, master, this knave would go sore.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Here is neither cheer, sir, nor welcome. We would fain have either.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: In debating which was best, we shall part with neither.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: They stand at the door, master; bid them welcome hither.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: There is something in the wind, that we cannot get in.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: You would say so, master, if your garments were thin. Your cake here is warm within; you stand here in the cold. It would make a man mad as a buck to be so bought and sold.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Go, fetch me something, I'll break ope the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Break any breaking here, and I'll break your knave's pate.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: A man may break a word with you, sir, and words are but wind; Ay, and break it in your face, so he break it not behind.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: It seems thou want'st breaking; out upon thee, hind!

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Here's too much "out upon thee"; I pray thee, let me in.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Ay, when fowls have no feathers and fish have no fin.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Well, I'll break in; go, borrow me a crow.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: A crow without feather; master, mean you so? For a fish without a fin, there's a fowl without a feather. If a crow help us in, sirrah, we'll pluck a crow together.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Go, get thee gone; fetch me an iron crow.

dialogues.speaker: Balthasar
dialogues.line: Have patience, sir. O, let it not be so: Herein you war against your reputation, And draw within the compass of suspect The unviolated honour of your wife. Once this,-your long experience of her wisdom, Her sober virtue, years, and modesty, Plead on her part some cause to you unknown; And doubt not, sir, but she will well excuse Why at this time the doors are made against you. Be rul'd by me; depart in patience, And let us to the Tiger all to dinner, And about evening, come yourself alone To know the reason of this strange restraint. If by strong hand you offer to break in Now in the stirring passage of the day, A vulgar comment will be made of it; And that supposed by the common rout Against your yet ungalled estimation That may with foul intrusion enter in, And dwell upon your grave when you are dead; For slander lives upon succession, For ever hous'd where it gets possession.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: You have prevail'd. I will depart in quiet, And, in despite of mirth, mean to be merry. I know a wench of excellent discourse, Pretty and witty; wild, and yet, too, gentle; There will we dine. This woman that I mean, My wife (but, I protest, without desert) Hath oftentimes upbraided me withal; To her will we to dinner.-Get you home And fetch the chain, by this I know 'tis made. Bring it, I pray you, to the Porpentine, For there's the house. That chain will I bestow (Be it for nothing but to spite my wife) Upon mine hostess there. Good sir, make haste. Since mine own doors refuse to entertain me, I'll knock elsewhere, to see if they'll disdain me.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I'll meet you at that place some hour hence.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Do so; this jest shall cost me some expense.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: And may it be that you have quite forgot A husband's office? Shall, Antipholus, Even in the spring of love, thy love-springs rot? Shall love, in building, grow so ruinous? If you did wed my sister for her wealth, Then for her wealth's sake use her with more kindness; Or if you like elsewhere, do it by stealth, Muffle your false love with some show of blindness. Let not my sister read it in your eye; Be not thy tongue thy own shame's orator; Look sweet, speak fair, become disloyalty; Apparel vice like virtue's harbinger; Bear a fair presence though your heart be tainted; Teach sin the carriage of a holy saint, Be secret-false. What need she be acquainted? What simple thief brags of his own attaint? 'Tis double wrong to truant with your bed And let her read it in thy looks at board. Shame hath a bastard fame, well managed; Ill deeds is doubled with an evil word. Alas, poor women, make us but believe, Being compact of credit, that you love us. Though others have the arm, show us the sleeve; We in your motion turn, and you may move us. Then, gentle brother, get you in again; Comfort my sister, cheer her, call her wife. 'Tis holy sport to be a little vain When the sweet breath of flattery conquers strife.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Sweet mistress, what your name is else, I know not, Nor by what wonder you do hit on mine; Less in your knowledge and your grace you show not Than our earth's wonder, more than earth divine. Teach me, dear creature, how to think and speak; Lay open to my earthy gross conceit, Smother'd in errors, feeble, shallow, weak, The folded meaning of your words' deceit. Against my soul's pure truth why labour you To make it wander in an unknown field? Are you a god? would you create me new? Transform me, then, and to your power I'll yield. But if that I am I, then well I know Your weeping sister is no wife of mine, Nor to her bed no homage do I owe. Far more, far more, to you do I decline. O, train me not, sweet mermaid, with thy note To drown me in thy sister's flood of tears. Sing, siren, for thyself, and I will dote; Spread o'er the silver waves thy golden hairs, And as a bed I'll take thee, and there lie, And, in that glorious supposition think He gains by death that hath such means to die. Let love, being light, be drowned if she sink!

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: What, are you mad, that you do reason so?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Not mad, but mated; how, I do not know.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: It is a fault that springeth from your eye.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: For gazing on your beams, fair sun, being by.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Gaze where you should, and that will clear your sight.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: As good to wink, sweet love, as look on night.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Why call you me love? Call my sister so.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Thy sister's sister.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: That's my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: No, It is thyself, mine own self's better part, Mine eye's clear eye, my dear heart's dearer heart, My food, my fortune, and my sweet hope's aim, My sole earth's heaven, and my heaven's claim.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: All this my sister is, or else should be.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Call thyself sister, sweet, for I aim thee; Thee will I love, and with thee lead my life; Thou hast no husband yet, nor I no wife. Give me thy hand.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: O, soft, sir, hold you still; I'll fetch my sister to get her goodwill.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Why, how now, Dromio? where runn'st thou so fast?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Do you know me, sir? Am I Dromio? Am I your man? Am I myself?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Thou art Dromio, thou art my man, thou art thyself.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I am an ass, I am a woman's man, and besides myself.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: What woman's man? and how besides thyself?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, besides myself, I am due to a woman, one that claims me, one that haunts me, one that will have me.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: What claim lays she to thee?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, such claim as you would lay to your horse, and she would have me as a beast; not that I being a beast she would have me, but that she being a very beastly creature lays claim to me.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: What is she?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: A very reverent body; ay, such a one as a man may not speak of without he say "sir-reverence". I have but lean luck in the match, and yet is she a wondrous fat marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: How dost thou mean a "fat marriage"?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, she's the kitchen wench, and all grease, and I know not what use to put her to but to make a lamp of her and run from her by her own light. I warrant her rags and the tallow in them will burn a Poland winter. If she lives till doomsday, she'll burn a week longer than the whole world.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: What complexion is she of?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Swart like my shoe, but her face nothing like so clean kept. For why? she sweats, a man may go overshoes in the grime of it.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: That's a fault that water will mend.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: No, sir, 'tis in grain; Noah's flood could not do it.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Nell, sir; but her name and three quarters, that's an ell and three quarters, will not measure her from hip to hip.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Then she bears some breadth?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: No longer from head to foot than from hip to hip. She is spherical, like a globe. I could find out countries in her.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: In what part of her body stands Ireland?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, in her buttocks; I found it out by the bogs.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Where Scotland?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I found it by the barrenness, hard in the palm of the hand.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Where France?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: In her forehead; armed and reverted, making war against her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Where England?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I looked for the chalky cliffs, but I could find no whiteness in them. But I guess it stood in her chin, by the salt rheum that ran between France and it.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Where Spain?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Faith, I saw it not; but I felt it hot in her breath.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Where America, the Indies?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: O, sir, upon her nose, all o'er-embellished with rubies, carbuncles, sapphires, declining their rich aspect to the hot breath of Spain, who sent whole armadoes of carracks to be ballast at her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Where stood Belgia, the Netherlands?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: O, sir, I did not look so low. To conclude: this drudge or diviner laid claim to me, called me Dromio, swore I was assured to her, told me what privy marks I had about me, as the mark of my shoulder, the mole in my neck, the great wart on my left arm, that I, amazed, ran from her as a witch. And, I think, if my breast had not been made of faith, and my heart of steel, she had transformed me to a curtal dog, and made me turn i' the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Go, hie thee presently, post to the road; And if the wind blow any way from shore, I will not harbour in this town tonight. If any bark put forth, come to the mart, Where I will walk till thou return to me. If everyone knows us, and we know none, 'Tis time, I think, to trudge, pack and be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: As from a bear a man would run for life, So fly I from her that would be my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: There's none but witches do inhabit here, And therefore 'tis high time that I were hence. She that doth call me husband, even my soul Doth for a wife abhor. But her fair sister, Possess'd with such a gentle sovereign grace, Of such enchanting presence and discourse, Hath almost made me traitor to myself. But lest myself be guilty to self-wrong, I'll stop mine ears against the mermaid's song.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Master Antipholus.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Ay, that's my name.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I know it well, sir. Lo, here is the chain; I thought to have ta'en you at the Porpentine, The chain unfinish'd made me stay thus long.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: What is your will that I shall do with this?

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: What please yourself, sir; I have made it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Made it for me, sir! I bespoke it not.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Not once, nor twice, but twenty times you have. Go home with it, and please your wife withal, And soon at supper-time I'll visit you, And then receive my money for the chain.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I pray you, sir, receive the money now, For fear you ne'er see chain nor money more.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: You are a merry man, sir; fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: What I should think of this I cannot tell, But this I think, there's no man is so vain That would refuse so fair an offer'd chain. I see a man here needs not live by shifts, When in the streets he meets such golden gifts. I'll to the mart, and there for Dromio stay; If any ship put out, then straight away.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: You know since Pentecost the sum is due, And since I have not much importun'd you, Nor now I had not, but that I am bound To Persia, and want guilders for my voyage; Therefore make present satisfaction, Or I'll attach you by this officer.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Even just the sum that I do owe to you Is growing to me by Antipholus, And in the instant that I met with you He had of me a chain; at five o'clock I shall receive the money for the same. Pleaseth you walk with me down to his house, I will discharge my bond, and thank you too. Courtesan's.

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: That labour may you save. See where he comes.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: While I go to the goldsmith's house, go thou And buy a rope's end; that will I bestow Among my wife and her confederates For locking me out of my doors by day. But soft, I see the goldsmith; get thee gone; Buy thou a rope, and bring it home to me.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I buy a thousand pound a year! I buy a rope!

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: A man is well holp up that trusts to you, I promised your presence and the chain, But neither chain nor goldsmith came to me. Belike you thought our love would last too long If it were chain'd together, and therefore came not.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Saving your merry humour, here's the note How much your chain weighs to the utmost carat, The fineness of the gold, and chargeful fashion, Which doth amount to three odd ducats more Than I stand debted to this gentleman. I pray you, see him presently discharg'd, For he is bound to sea, and stays but for it.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I am not furnished with the present money; Besides, I have some business in the town. Good signior, take the stranger to my house, And with you take the chain, and bid my wife Disburse the sum on the receipt thereof; Perchance I will be there as soon as you.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Then you will bring the chain to her yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: No, bear it with you, lest I come not time enough.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Well, sir, I will. Have you the chain about you?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: And if I have not, sir, I hope you have, Or else you may return without your money.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Nay, come, I pray you, sir, give me the chain; Both wind and tide stays for this gentleman, And I, to blame, have held him here too long.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Good Lord, you use this dalliance to excuse Your breach of promise to the Porpentine. I should have chid you for not bringing it, But, like a shrew, you first begin to brawl.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: The hour steals on; I pray you, sir, dispatch.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: You hear how he importunes me. The chain!

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Why, give it to my wife, and fetch your money.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Come, come, you know I gave it you even now. Either send the chain or send by me some token.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Fie, now you run this humour out of breath. Come, where's the chain? I pray you, let me see it.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: My business cannot brook this dalliance. Good sir, say whe'er you'll answer me or no; If not, I'll leave him to the officer.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I answer you? What should I answer you?

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: The money that you owe me for the chain.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I owe you none till I receive the chain.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: You know I gave it you half an hour since.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: You gave me none. You wrong me much to say so.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: You wrong me more, sir, in denying it. Consider how it stands upon my credit.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: Well, officer, arrest him at my suit.

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: I do, and charge you in the duke's name to obey me.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: This touches me in reputation. Either consent to pay this sum for me, Or I attach you by this officer.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Consent to pay thee that I never had? Arrest me, foolish fellow, if thou dar'st.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Here is thy fee; arrest him, officer. I would not spare my brother in this case If he should scorn me so apparently.

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: I do arrest you, sir. You hear the suit.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I do obey thee till I give thee bail. But, sirrah, you shall buy this sport as dear As all the metal in your shop will answer.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Sir, sir, I shall have law in Ephesus, To your notorious shame, I doubt it not.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Master, there's a bark of Epidamnum That stays but till her owner comes aboard, And then, sir, bears away. Our fraughtage, sir, I have convey'd aboard, and I have bought The oil, the balsamum, and aqua-vitae. The ship is in her trim; the merry wind Blows fair from land; they stay for nought at all But for their owner, master, and yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: How now? a madman? Why, thou peevish sheep, What ship of Epidamnum stays for me?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: A ship you sent me to, to hire waftage.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Thou drunken slave, I sent thee for a rope, And told thee to what purpose and what end.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: You sent me for a rope's end as soon. You sent me to the bay, sir, for a bark.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I will debate this matter at more leisure, And teach your ears to list me with more heed. To Adriana, villain, hie thee straight: Give her this key, and tell her in the desk That's cover'd o'er with Turkish tapestry There is a purse of ducats; let her send it. Tell her I am arrested in the street, And that shall bail me. Hie thee, slave; be gone. On, officer, to prison till it come.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: To Adriana, that is where we din'd, Where Dowsabel did claim me for her husband. She is too big, I hope, for me to compass. Thither I must, although against my will, For servants must their masters' minds fulfil.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Ah, Luciana, did he tempt thee so? Might'st thou perceive austerely in his eye That he did plead in earnest, yea or no? Look'd he or red or pale, or sad or merrily? What observation mad'st thou in this case Of his heart's meteors tilting in his face?

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: First he denied you had in him no right.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: He meant he did me none; the more my spite.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Then swore he that he was a stranger here.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: And true he swore, though yet forsworn he were.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Then pleaded I for you.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: And what said he?

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: That love I begg'd for you he begg'd of me.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: With what persuasion did he tempt thy love?

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: With words that in an honest suit might move. First he did praise my beauty, then my speech.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Did'st speak him fair?

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Have patience, I beseech.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: I cannot, nor I will not hold me still. My tongue, though not my heart, shall have his will. He is deformed, crooked, old, and sere, Ill-fac'd, worse bodied, shapeless everywhere; Vicious, ungentle, foolish, blunt, unkind, Stigmatical in making, worse in mind.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Who would be jealous then of such a one? No evil lost is wail'd when it is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Ah, but I think him better than I say, And yet would herein others' eyes were worse: Far from her nest the lapwing cries away; My heart prays for him, though my tongue do curse.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Here, go; the desk, the purse, sweet now, make haste.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: How hast thou lost thy breath?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: By running fast.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Where is thy master, Dromio? is he well?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: No, he's in Tartar limbo, worse than hell. A devil in an everlasting garment hath him, One whose hard heart is button'd up with steel; A fiend, a fairy, pitiless and rough; A wolf, nay worse, a fellow all in buff; A back-friend, a shoulder-clapper, one that countermands The passages of alleys, creeks, and narrow lands; A hound that runs counter, and yet draws dryfoot well, One that, before the judgement, carries poor souls to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Why, man, what is the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I do not know the matter. He is 'rested on the case.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: What, is he arrested? Tell me at whose suit?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I know not at whose suit he is arrested, well; But he's in a suit of buff which 'rested him, that can I tell. Will you send him, mistress, redemption, the money in his desk?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Go fetch it, sister. This I wonder at, Thus he unknown to me should be in debt. Tell me, was he arrested on a band?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Not on a band, but on a stronger thing; A chain, a chain. Do you not hear it ring?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: What, the chain?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: No, no, the bell, 'tis time that I were gone. It was two ere I left him, and now the clock strikes one.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: The hours come back! That did I never hear.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: O yes, if any hour meet a sergeant, 'a turns back for very fear.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: As if time were in debt. How fondly dost thou reason!

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Time is a very bankrupt, and owes more than he's worth to season. Nay, he's a thief too. Have you not heard men say That time comes stealing on by night and day? If he be in debt and theft, and a sergeant in the way, Hath he not reason to turn back an hour in a day?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Go, Dromio, there's the money, bear it straight, And bring thy master home immediately. Come, sister, I am press'd down with conceit; Conceit, my comfort and my injury.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: There's not a man I meet but doth salute me As if I were their well-acquainted friend, And everyone doth call me by my name. Some tender money to me, some invite me; Some other give me thanks for kindnesses; Some offer me commodities to buy. Even now a tailor call'd me in his shop, And show'd me silks that he had bought for me, And therewithal took measure of my body. Sure, these are but imaginary wiles, And Lapland sorcerers inhabit here.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Master, here's the gold you sent me for. What, have you got the picture of old Adam new apparelled?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: What gold is this? What Adam dost thou mean?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Not that Adam that kept the paradise, but that Adam that keeps the prison; he that goes in the calf's skin that was killed for the Prodigal; he that came behind you, sir, like an evil angel, and bid you forsake your liberty.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I understand thee not.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: No? Why, 'tis a plain case: he that went like a bass-viol in a case of leather; the man, sir, that, when gentlemen are tired, gives them a sob, and 'rests them; he, sir, that takes pity on decayed men and gives them suits of durance; he that sets up his rest to do more exploits with his mace than a morris-pike.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: What! thou mean'st an officer?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, the sergeant of the band; he that brings any man to answer it that breaks his band; one that thinks a man always going to bed, and says, "God give you good rest."

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Well, sir, there rest in your foolery. Is there any ship puts forth tonight? may we be gone?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Why, sir, I brought you word an hour since that the bark _Expedition_ put forth tonight, and then were you hindered by the sergeant to tarry for the hoy _Delay_. Here are the angels that you sent for to deliver you.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: The fellow is distract, and so am I, And here we wander in illusions. Some blessed power deliver us from hence!

dialogues.speaker: Courtesan
dialogues.line: Well met, well met, Master Antipholus. I see, sir, you have found the goldsmith now. Is that the chain you promis'd me today?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Satan, avoid! I charge thee, tempt me not.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Master, is this Mistress Satan?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: It is the devil.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Nay, she is worse, she is the devil's dam; and here she comes in the habit of a light wench, and thereof comes that the wenches say "God damn me", that's as much to say, "God make me a light wench." It is written they appear to men like angels of light. Light is an effect of fire, and fire will burn; ergo, light wenches will burn. Come not near her.

dialogues.speaker: Courtesan
dialogues.line: Your man and you are marvellous merry, sir. Will you go with me? We'll mend our dinner here.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Master, if you do, expect spoon-meat, or bespeak a long spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Why, Dromio?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Marry, he must have a long spoon that must eat with the devil.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Avoid then, fiend! What tell'st thou me of supping? Thou art, as you are all, a sorceress. I conjure thee to leave me and be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Courtesan
dialogues.line: Give me the ring of mine you had at dinner, Or, for my diamond, the chain you promis'd, And I'll be gone, sir, and not trouble you.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Some devils ask but the paring of one's nail, A rush, a hair, a drop of blood, a pin, A nut, a cherry-stone; but she, more covetous, Would have a chain. Master, be wise; and if you give it her, The devil will shake her chain and fright us with it.

dialogues.speaker: Courtesan
dialogues.line: I pray you, sir, my ring, or else the chain; I hope you do not mean to cheat me so.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Avaunt, thou witch! Come, Dromio, let us go.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Fly pride, says the peacock. Mistress, that you know.

dialogues.speaker: Courtesan
dialogues.line: Now, out of doubt Antipholus is mad, Else would he never so demean himself. A ring he hath of mine worth forty ducats, And for the same he promis'd me a chain; Both one and other he denies me now. The reason that I gather he is mad, Besides this present instance of his rage, Is a mad tale he told today at dinner Of his own doors being shut against his entrance. Belike his wife, acquainted with his fits, On purpose shut the doors against his way. My way is now to hie home to his house, And tell his wife that, being lunatic, He rush'd into my house and took perforce My ring away. This course I fittest choose, For forty ducats is too much to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Fear me not, man, I will not break away: I'll give thee ere I leave thee so much money, To warrant thee, as I am 'rested for. My wife is in a wayward mood today, And will not lightly trust the messenger That I should be attach'd in Ephesus; I tell you 'twill sound harshly in her ears. Enter Dromio of Ephesus with a rope's end. Here comes my man. I think he brings the money. How now, sir! have you that I sent you for?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Here's that, I warrant you, will pay them all.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: But where's the money?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Why, sir, I gave the money for the rope.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Five hundred ducats, villain, for a rope?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I'll serve you, sir, five hundred at the rate.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: To what end did I bid thee hie thee home?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: To a rope's end, sir; and to that end am I return'd.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: And to that end, sir, I will welcome you.

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: Good sir, be patient.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Nay, 'tis for me to be patient. I am in adversity.

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: Good now, hold thy tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Nay, rather persuade him to hold his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Thou whoreson, senseless villain.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I would I were senseless, sir, that I might not feel your blows.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Thou art sensible in nothing but blows, and so is an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I am an ass indeed; you may prove it by my long ears. I have served him from the hour of my nativity to this instant, and have nothing at his hands for my service but blows. When I am cold, he heats me with beating; when I am warm he cools me with beating. I am waked with it when I sleep, raised with it when I sit, driven out of doors with it when I go from home, welcomed home with it when I return. Nay, I bear it on my shoulders as a beggar wont her brat; and I think when he hath lamed me, I shall beg with it from door to door.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Come, go along, my wife is coming yonder.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Mistress, _respice finem_, respect your end, or rather, the prophesy like the parrot, "Beware the rope's end."

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Wilt thou still talk?

dialogues.speaker: Courtesan
dialogues.line: How say you now? Is not your husband mad?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: His incivility confirms no less. Good Doctor Pinch, you are a conjurer; Establish him in his true sense again, And I will please you what you will demand.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Alas, how fiery and how sharp he looks!

dialogues.speaker: Courtesan
dialogues.line: Mark how he trembles in his ecstasy.

dialogues.speaker: Pinch
dialogues.line: Give me your hand, and let me feel your pulse.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: There is my hand, and let it feel your ear.

dialogues.speaker: Pinch
dialogues.line: I charge thee, Satan, hous'd within this man, To yield possession to my holy prayers, And to thy state of darkness hie thee straight. I conjure thee by all the saints in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Peace, doting wizard, peace; I am not mad.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: O, that thou wert not, poor distressed soul!

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: You minion, you, are these your customers? Did this companion with the saffron face Revel and feast it at my house today, Whilst upon me the guilty doors were shut, And I denied to enter in my house?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: O husband, God doth know you din'd at home, Where would you had remain'd until this time, Free from these slanders and this open shame.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Din'd at home? Thou villain, what sayest thou?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Sir, sooth to say, you did not dine at home.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Were not my doors lock'd up and I shut out?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Perdy, your doors were lock'd, and you shut out.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: And did not she herself revile me there?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Sans fable, she herself revil'd you there.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Did not her kitchen-maid rail, taunt, and scorn me?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Certes, she did, the kitchen-vestal scorn'd you.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: And did not I in rage depart from thence?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: In verity, you did; my bones bear witness, That since have felt the vigour of his rage.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Is't good to soothe him in these contraries?

dialogues.speaker: Pinch
dialogues.line: It is no shame; the fellow finds his vein, And yielding to him, humours well his frenzy.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Thou hast suborn'd the goldsmith to arrest me.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Alas! I sent you money to redeem you By Dromio here, who came in haste for it.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Money by me? Heart and goodwill you might, But surely, master, not a rag of money.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Went'st not thou to her for a purse of ducats?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: He came to me, and I deliver'd it.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: And I am witness with her that she did.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: God and the rope-maker bear me witness That I was sent for nothing but a rope.

dialogues.speaker: Pinch
dialogues.line: Mistress, both man and master is possess'd, I know it by their pale and deadly looks. They must be bound and laid in some dark room.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Say, wherefore didst thou lock me forth today, And why dost thou deny the bag of gold?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: I did not, gentle husband, lock thee forth.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: And gentle master, I receiv'd no gold; But I confess, sir, that we were lock'd out.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Dissembling villain, thou speak'st false in both.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Dissembling harlot, thou art false in all, And art confederate with a damned pack To make a loathsome abject scorn of me. But with these nails I'll pluck out these false eyes That would behold in me this shameful sport.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: O, bind him, bind him; let him not come near me.

dialogues.speaker: Pinch
dialogues.line: More company; the fiend is strong within him.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Ay me, poor man, how pale and wan he looks!

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: What, will you murder me? Thou jailer, thou, I am thy prisoner. Wilt thou suffer them To make a rescue?

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: Masters, let him go. He is my prisoner, and you shall not have him.

dialogues.speaker: Pinch
dialogues.line: Go, bind this man, for he is frantic too.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: What wilt thou do, thou peevish officer? Hast thou delight to see a wretched man Do outrage and displeasure to himself?

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: He is my prisoner. If I let him go, The debt he owes will be requir'd of me.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: I will discharge thee ere I go from thee; Bear me forthwith unto his creditor, And knowing how the debt grows, I will pay it. Good master doctor, see him safe convey'd Home to my house. O most unhappy day!

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: O most unhappy strumpet!

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Master, I am here enter'd in bond for you.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Out on thee, villain! wherefore dost thou mad me?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Will you be bound for nothing? Be mad, good master; cry, "the devil".

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: God help, poor souls, how idly do they talk!

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Go bear him hence. Sister, go you with me.  Say now, whose suit is he arrested at?

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: One Angelo, a goldsmith; do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: I know the man. What is the sum he owes?

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: Two hundred ducats.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Say, how grows it due?

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: Due for a chain your husband had of him.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: He did bespeak a chain for me, but had it not.

dialogues.speaker: Courtesan
dialogues.line: When as your husband, all in rage, today Came to my house and took away my ring, The ring I saw upon his finger now, Straight after did I meet him with a chain.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: It may be so, but I did never see it. Come, jailer, bring me where the goldsmith is, I long to know the truth hereof at large. Syracuse.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: God, for thy mercy, they are loose again!

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: And come with naked swords. Let's call more help To have them bound again.

dialogues.speaker: Officer
