dialogues.line: Away, they'll kill us.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I see these witches are afraid of swords.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: She that would be your wife now ran from you.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Come to the Centaur, fetch our stuff from thence. I long that we were safe and sound aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Faith, stay here this night, they will surely do us no harm; you saw they speak us fair, give us gold. Methinks they are such a gentle nation that, but for the mountain of mad flesh that claims marriage of me, I could find in my heart to stay here still and turn witch.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I will not stay tonight for all the town; Therefore away, to get our stuff aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I am sorry, sir, that I have hinder'd you, But I protest he had the chain of me, Though most dishonestly he doth deny it.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: How is the man esteem'd here in the city?

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Of very reverend reputation, sir, Of credit infinite, highly belov'd, Second to none that lives here in the city. His word might bear my wealth at any time.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: Speak softly. Yonder, as I think, he walks.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: 'Tis so; and that self chain about his neck Which he forswore most monstrously to have. Good sir, draw near to me, I'll speak to him. Signior Antipholus, I wonder much That you would put me to this shame and trouble, And not without some scandal to yourself, With circumstance and oaths so to deny This chain, which now you wear so openly. Beside the charge, the shame, imprisonment, You have done wrong to this my honest friend, Who, but for staying on our controversy, Had hoisted sail and put to sea today. This chain you had of me, can you deny it?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I think I had: I never did deny it.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: Yes, that you did, sir, and forswore it too.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Who heard me to deny it or forswear it?

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: These ears of mine, thou know'st, did hear thee. Fie on thee, wretch. 'Tis pity that thou liv'st To walk where any honest men resort.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Thou art a villain to impeach me thus; I'll prove mine honour and mine honesty Against thee presently, if thou dar'st stand.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: I dare, and do defy thee for a villain.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Hold, hurt him not, for God's sake, he is mad. Some get within him, take his sword away. Bind Dromio too, and bear them to my house.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Run, master, run, for God's sake, take a house. This is some priory; in, or we are spoil'd.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: Be quiet, people. Wherefore throng you hither?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: To fetch my poor distracted husband hence. Let us come in, that we may bind him fast And bear him home for his recovery.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I knew he was not in his perfect wits.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: I am sorry now that I did draw on him.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: How long hath this possession held the man?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: This week he hath been heavy, sour, sad, And much different from the man he was. But till this afternoon his passion Ne'er brake into extremity of rage.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: Hath he not lost much wealth by wreck of sea? Buried some dear friend? Hath not else his eye Stray'd his affection in unlawful love? A sin prevailing much in youthful men Who give their eyes the liberty of gazing? Which of these sorrows is he subject to?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: To none of these, except it be the last, Namely, some love that drew him oft from home.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: You should for that have reprehended him.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Why, so I did.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: Ay, but not rough enough.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: As roughly as my modesty would let me.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: Haply in private.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: And in assemblies too.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: Ay, but not enough.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: It was the copy of our conference. In bed he slept not for my urging it; At board he fed not for my urging it; Alone, it was the subject of my theme; In company I often glanced it; Still did I tell him it was vile and bad.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: And thereof came it that the man was mad. The venom clamours of a jealous woman Poisons more deadly than a mad dog's tooth. It seems his sleeps were hindered by thy railing, And thereof comes it that his head is light. Thou say'st his meat was sauc'd with thy upbraidings. Unquiet meals make ill digestions; Thereof the raging fire of fever bred, And what's a fever but a fit of madness? Thou say'st his sports were hinder'd by thy brawls. Sweet recreation barr'd, what doth ensue But moody and dull melancholy, Kinsman to grim and comfortless despair, And at her heels a huge infectious troop Of pale distemperatures and foes to life? In food, in sport, and life-preserving rest To be disturb'd would mad or man or beast. The consequence is, then, thy jealous fits Hath scar'd thy husband from the use of's wits.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: She never reprehended him but mildly, When he demean'd himself rough, rude, and wildly. Why bear you these rebukes and answer not?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: She did betray me to my own reproof. Good people, enter and lay hold on him.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: No, not a creature enters in my house.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Then let your servants bring my husband forth.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: Neither. He took this place for sanctuary, And it shall privilege him from your hands Till I have brought him to his wits again, Or lose my labour in assaying it.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: I will attend my husband, be his nurse, Diet his sickness, for it is my office, And will have no attorney but myself; And therefore let me have him home with me.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: Be patient, for I will not let him stir Till I have used the approved means I have, With wholesome syrups, drugs, and holy prayers, To make of him a formal man again. It is a branch and parcel of mine oath, A charitable duty of my order; Therefore depart, and leave him here with me.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: I will not hence and leave my husband here; And ill it doth beseem your holiness To separate the husband and the wife.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: Be quiet and depart. Thou shalt not have him.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Complain unto the duke of this indignity.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Come, go. I will fall prostrate at his feet, And never rise until my tears and prayers Have won his grace to come in person hither And take perforce my husband from the abbess.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: By this, I think, the dial points at five. Anon, I'm sure, the Duke himself in person Comes this way to the melancholy vale, The place of death and sorry execution Behind the ditches of the abbey here.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Upon what cause?

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: To see a reverend Syracusian merchant, Who put unluckily into this bay Against the laws and statutes of this town, Beheaded publicly for his offence.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: See where they come. We will behold his death.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Kneel to the Duke before he pass the abbey. Enter the Duke, attended; Egeon, bareheaded; with the Headsman and other Officers.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Yet once again proclaim it publicly, If any friend will pay the sum for him, He shall not die; so much we tender him.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Justice, most sacred duke, against the abbess!

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: She is a virtuous and a reverend lady, It cannot be that she hath done thee wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: May it please your grace, Antipholus, my husband, Who I made lord of me and all I had At your important letters, this ill day A most outrageous fit of madness took him; That desp'rately he hurried through the street, With him his bondman all as mad as he, Doing displeasure to the citizens By rushing in their houses, bearing thence Rings, jewels, anything his rage did like. Once did I get him bound and sent him home, Whilst to take order for the wrongs I went, That here and there his fury had committed. Anon, I wot not by what strong escape, He broke from those that had the guard of him, And with his mad attendant and himself, Each one with ireful passion, with drawn swords, Met us again, and, madly bent on us, Chased us away; till raising of more aid, We came again to bind them. Then they fled Into this abbey, whither we pursued them. And here the abbess shuts the gates on us, And will not suffer us to fetch him out, Nor send him forth that we may bear him hence. Therefore, most gracious duke, with thy command Let him be brought forth and borne hence for help.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Long since thy husband serv'd me in my wars, And I to thee engag'd a prince's word, When thou didst make him master of thy bed, To do him all the grace and good I could. Go, some of you, knock at the abbey gate, And bid the lady abbess come to me. I will determine this before I stir.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: O mistress, mistress, shift and save yourself. My master and his man are both broke loose, Beaten the maids a-row, and bound the doctor, Whose beard they have singed off with brands of fire, And ever as it blazed they threw on him Great pails of puddled mire to quench the hair. My master preaches patience to him, and the while His man with scissors nicks him like a fool; And sure (unless you send some present help) Between them they will kill the conjurer.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Peace, fool, thy master and his man are here, And that is false thou dost report to us.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Mistress, upon my life, I tell you true. I have not breath'd almost since I did see it. He cries for you, and vows, if he can take you, To scorch your face and to disfigure you. Hark, hark, I hear him, mistress. Fly, be gone!

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Come, stand by me, fear nothing. Guard with halberds.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Ay me, it is my husband. Witness you That he is borne about invisible. Even now we hous'd him in the abbey here, And now he's there, past thought of human reason.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Justice, most gracious duke; O, grant me justice! Even for the service that long since I did thee When I bestrid thee in the wars, and took Deep scars to save thy life; even for the blood That then I lost for thee, now grant me justice.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: Unless the fear of death doth make me dote, I see my son Antipholus and Dromio.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Justice, sweet prince, against that woman there. She whom thou gav'st to me to be my wife; That hath abused and dishonour'd me Even in the strength and height of injury. Beyond imagination is the wrong That she this day hath shameless thrown on me.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Discover how, and thou shalt find me just.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: This day, great duke, she shut the doors upon me While she with harlots feasted in my house.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: A grievous fault. Say, woman, didst thou so?

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: No, my good lord. Myself, he, and my sister Today did dine together. So befall my soul As this is false he burdens me withal.

dialogues.speaker: Luciana
dialogues.line: Ne'er may I look on day nor sleep on night But she tells to your highness simple truth.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: O perjur'd woman! They are both forsworn. In this the madman justly chargeth them.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: My liege, I am advised what I say, Neither disturb'd with the effect of wine, Nor heady-rash, provok'd with raging ire, Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad. This woman lock'd me out this day from dinner. That goldsmith there, were he not pack'd with her, Could witness it, for he was with me then, Who parted with me to go fetch a chain, Promising to bring it to the Porpentine, Where Balthasar and I did dine together. Our dinner done, and he not coming thither, I went to seek him. In the street I met him, And in his company that gentleman. There did this perjur'd goldsmith swear me down That I this day of him receiv'd the chain, Which, God he knows, I saw not. For the which He did arrest me with an officer. I did obey, and sent my peasant home For certain ducats. He with none return'd. Then fairly I bespoke the officer To go in person with me to my house. By th' way we met My wife, her sister, and a rabble more Of vile confederates. Along with them They brought one Pinch, a hungry lean-faced villain, A mere anatomy, a mountebank, A threadbare juggler, and a fortune-teller; A needy, hollow-ey'd, sharp-looking wretch; A living dead man. This pernicious slave, Forsooth, took on him as a conjurer, And gazing in mine eyes, feeling my pulse, And with no face (as 'twere) outfacing me, Cries out, I was possess'd. Then altogether They fell upon me, bound me, bore me thence, And in a dark and dankish vault at home There left me and my man, both bound together, Till gnawing with my teeth my bonds in sunder, I gain'd my freedom and immediately Ran hither to your Grace, whom I beseech To give me ample satisfaction For these deep shames and great indignities.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: My lord, in truth, thus far I witness with him, That he din'd not at home, but was lock'd out.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: But had he such a chain of thee, or no?

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: He had, my lord, and when he ran in here These people saw the chain about his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Merchant
dialogues.line: Besides, I will be sworn these ears of mine Heard you confess you had the chain of him, After you first forswore it on the mart, And thereupon I drew my sword on you; And then you fled into this abbey here, From whence I think you are come by miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I never came within these abbey walls, Nor ever didst thou draw thy sword on me. I never saw the chain, so help me heaven; And this is false you burden me withal.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Why, what an intricate impeach is this! I think you all have drunk of Circe's cup. If here you hous'd him, here he would have been. If he were mad, he would not plead so coldly. You say he din'd at home, the goldsmith here Denies that saying. Sirrah, what say you?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Sir, he dined with her there, at the Porpentine.

dialogues.speaker: Courtesan
dialogues.line: He did, and from my finger snatch'd that ring.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: 'Tis true, my liege, this ring I had of her.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Saw'st thou him enter at the abbey here?

dialogues.speaker: Courtesan
dialogues.line: As sure, my liege, as I do see your grace.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Why, this is strange. Go call the abbess hither. I think you are all mated, or stark mad.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: Most mighty Duke, vouchsafe me speak a word; Haply I see a friend will save my life And pay the sum that may deliver me.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Speak freely, Syracusian, what thou wilt.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: Is not your name, sir, call'd Antipholus? And is not that your bondman Dromio?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: But he, I thank him, gnaw'd in two my cords. Now am I Dromio, and his man, unbound.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: I am sure you both of you remember me.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Ourselves we do remember, sir, by you. For lately we were bound as you are now. You are not Pinch's patient, are you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: Why look you strange on me? you know me well.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I never saw you in my life till now.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: O! grief hath chang'd me since you saw me last, And careful hours with time's deformed hand, Have written strange defeatures in my face. But tell me yet, dost thou not know my voice?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Neither.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: Dromio, nor thou?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: No, trust me, sir, nor I.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: I am sure thou dost.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, but I am sure I do not, and whatsoever a man denies, you are now bound to believe him.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: Not know my voice! O time's extremity, Hast thou so crack'd and splitted my poor tongue In seven short years that here my only son Knows not my feeble key of untun'd cares? Though now this grained face of mine be hid In sap-consuming winter's drizzled snow, And all the conduits of my blood froze up, Yet hath my night of life some memory, My wasting lamps some fading glimmer left, My dull deaf ears a little use to hear. All these old witnesses, I cannot err, Tell me thou art my son Antipholus.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I never saw my father in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: But seven years since, in Syracusa, boy, Thou know'st we parted; but perhaps, my son, Thou sham'st to acknowledge me in misery.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: The duke and all that know me in the city, Can witness with me that it is not so. I ne'er saw Syracusa in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I tell thee, Syracusian, twenty years Have I been patron to Antipholus, During which time he ne'er saw Syracusa. I see thy age and dangers make thee dote.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: Most mighty duke, behold a man much wrong'd.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: I see two husbands, or mine eyes deceive me.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: One of these men is _genius_ to the other; And so of these, which is the natural man, And which the spirit? Who deciphers them?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I, sir, am Dromio, command him away.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I, sir, am Dromio, pray let me stay.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Egeon, art thou not? or else his ghost?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: O, my old master, who hath bound him here?

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: Whoever bound him, I will loose his bonds, And gain a husband by his liberty. Speak, old Egeon, if thou be'st the man That hadst a wife once called Emilia, That bore thee at a burden two fair sons. O, if thou be'st the same Egeon, speak, And speak unto the same Emilia!

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Why, here begins his morning story right: These two Antipholus', these two so like, And these two Dromios, one in semblance, Besides her urging of her wreck at sea. These are the parents to these children, Which accidentally are met together.

dialogues.speaker: Egeon
dialogues.line: If I dream not, thou art Emilia. If thou art she, tell me where is that son That floated with thee on the fatal raft?

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: By men of Epidamnum, he and I And the twin Dromio, all were taken up; But, by and by, rude fishermen of Corinth By force took Dromio and my son from them, And me they left with those of Epidamnum. What then became of them I cannot tell; I to this fortune that you see me in.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Antipholus, thou cam'st from Corinth first?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: No, sir, not I, I came from Syracuse.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Stay, stand apart, I know not which is which.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: I came from Corinth, my most gracious lord.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: And I with him.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Brought to this town by that most famous warrior, Duke Menaphon, your most renowned uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: Which of you two did dine with me today?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I, gentle mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: And are not you my husband?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: No, I say nay to that.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: And so do I, yet did she call me so; And this fair gentlewoman, her sister here, Did call me brother. What I told you then, I hope I shall have leisure to make good, If this be not a dream I see and hear.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: That is the chain, sir, which you had of me.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: I think it be, sir. I deny it not.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: And you, sir, for this chain arrested me.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I think I did, sir. I deny it not.

dialogues.speaker: Adriana
dialogues.line: I sent you money, sir, to be your bail By Dromio, but I think he brought it not.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: No, none by me.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: This purse of ducats I receiv'd from you, And Dromio my man did bring them me. I see we still did meet each other's man, And I was ta'en for him, and he for me, And thereupon these errors are arose.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: These ducats pawn I for my father here.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: It shall not need, thy father hath his life.

dialogues.speaker: Courtesan
dialogues.line: Sir, I must have that diamond from you.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: There, take it, and much thanks for my good cheer.

dialogues.speaker: Abbess
dialogues.line: Renowned duke, vouchsafe to take the pains To go with us into the abbey here, And hear at large discoursed all our fortunes; And all that are assembled in this place, That by this sympathised one day's error Have suffer'd wrong, go, keep us company, And we shall make full satisfaction. Thirty-three years have I but gone in travail Of you, my sons, and till this present hour My heavy burden ne'er delivered. The duke, my husband, and my children both, And you, the calendars of their nativity, Go to a gossips' feast, and go with me. After so long grief, such nativity.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: With all my heart, I'll gossip at this feast.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Master, shall I fetch your stuff from shipboard?

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Dromio, what stuff of mine hast thou embark'd?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Your goods that lay at host, sir, in the Centaur.

dialogues.speaker: Antipholus Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: He speaks to me; I am your master, Dromio. Come, go with us. We'll look to that anon. Embrace thy brother there, rejoice with him.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: There is a fat friend at your master's house, That kitchen'd me for you today at dinner. She now shall be my sister, not my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Methinks you are my glass, and not my brother. I see by you I am a sweet-faced youth. Will you walk in to see their gossiping?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: Not I, sir, you are my elder.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: That's a question, how shall we try it?

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Syracuse
dialogues.line: We'll draw cuts for the senior. Till then, lead thou first.

dialogues.speaker: Dromio Of Ephesus
dialogues.line: Nay, then, thus: We came into the world like brother and brother, And now let's go hand in hand, not one before another.
